data.question: What is the general formula for the dimeric species formed when bis(hexafluoroacetylacetonato)manganese(II) trihydrate reacts with 4,4‘-trimethylenedipyridine in the presence of toluene?
Which guest molecule, when used in the crystallization of the metal−ligand system 1/2, leads to the formation of an infinite coordination polymer instead of closed dinuclear macrocycles?

What is the outcome of the competition experiment between nitrobenzene and cyanobenzene as guests in the reaction of 4,4‘-trimethylenedipyridine and bis(hexafluoroacetylacetonato)manganese(II) trihydrate?

What type of interactions differentiate the solid-state products formed when bis(hexafluoroacetylacetonato)manganese(II) trihydrate reacts with 4,4‘-trimethylenedipyridine in the presence of various guests?
data.answer: Weak intermolecular interactions between the guest molecules themselves and/or with the host

data.question: How does the use of a less rigid donor linker, such as 4,4‘-trimethylenedipyridine, affect the crystal engineering strategy?
data.answer: It changes the metal−ligand system from an infinite helix to both closed dinuclear macrocycles and a wedge-shaped, syndiotactic polymer

data.question: What role do the simple organic templates play in the formation of different solid-state arrangements?
data.answer: They form a variety of weak intermolecular interactions that highly influence the overall crystal-topology of the resulting solid-state assembly

data.question: Why does the reaction of 4,4‘-trimethylenedipyridine and bis(hexafluoroacetylacetonato)manganese(II) trihydrate with 1,3-diphenylpropane lead to a syndiotactic polymer instead of closed macrocycles?
data.answer: The size of the guest molecule, 1,3-diphenylpropane, plays a crucial role, leading to C−H···π interactions that preclude the assembly of a dimeric ring system

data.question: What is the result of the competition experiment between toluene and nitrobenzene as guests in the reaction of 4,4‘-trimethylenedipyridine and bis(hexafluoroacetylacetonato)manganese(II) trihydrate?
data.answer: The toluene enclathrated material is the sole product

data.question: How does the presence of nitrobenzene influence the solid-state structure of its complex with 4,4‘-trimethylenedipyridine and bis(hexafluoroacetylacetonato)manganese(II) trihydrate?
data.answer: Nitrobenzene leads to the formation of infinite guest columns through nonclassical hydrogen bonding between included solvent molecules

data.question: Is the solid-state product formed with benzyl alcohol as a guest in the reaction of 4,4‘-trimethylenedipyridine and bis(hexafluoroacetylacetonato)manganese(II) trihydrate isostructural to the toluene complex?
data.answer: Yes, the benzyl alcohol complex is isostructural to the toluene system

data.question: Does the crystallization of 4,4‘-trimethylenedipyridine and bis(hexafluoroacetylacetonato)manganese(II) trihydrate in the presence of cyanobenzene result in a host−guest complex that is isostructural to the nitrobenzene complex?
Do the complexes formed with nitrobenzene and cyanobenzene as guests exhibit any interactions with the host framework?
data.answer: False, they exhibit no interactions with the host framework

data.question: Is the formation of the syndiotactic polymer observed when 4,4‘-trimethylenedipyridine and bis(hexafluoroacetylacetonato)manganese(II) trihydrate react with 1,3-diphenylpropane due to the formation of hydrophobic host−guest interactions?
data.answer: False, it is due to C−H···π interactions that preclude the assembly of a dimeric ring system
